mainEntity.name: Are you licensed and insured for deck construction projects?

acceptedAnswer.text: Reputable deck contractors should carry: (1) A valid state contractor's license (verify through your state licensing board), (2) General liability insurance ($1M+ coverage), and (3) Workers' compensation. For elevated decks over 30 inches, many states require additional structural engineering certifications. Always request current certificates and verify coverage directly with insurers - uninsured contractors risk making homeowners liable for accidents.

mainEntity.name: What types of decking materials do you specialize in?

acceptedAnswer.text: Quality contractors typically work with: (1) Pressure-treated wood (most affordable at $15-$25/sq ft installed), (2) Composite decking (low-maintenance, $30-$45/sq ft), (3) PVC (mold-resistant, $35-$55/sq ft), and (4) Tropical hardwoods like ipe (premium, $40-$70/sq ft). Specialization matters - composite installers need different tools/fasteners than wood experts. Ask about manufacturer certifications (e.g., TrexPro or TimberTech Platinum installers).

mainEntity.name: Can you provide references or a portfolio of completed decks?

acceptedAnswer.text: Professional deck builders should offer: (1) 3-5 recent client references (call to ask about cleanup, timelines), (2) Before/after photos of similar projects, (3) Addresses of local installations you can drive by, and (4) Reviews on third-party sites like Houzz. Beware of contractors who only show catalog photos - reputable ones document actual completed work with close-ups of railings, stairs, and structural details.

mainEntity.name: How do you handle unexpected problems or project delays?

acceptedAnswer.text: Experienced deck contractors plan for: (1) Material delays (keep 10% extra lumber on-site), (2) Weather (include buffer days in contract), (3) Hidden rot/structural issues (perform pre-build inspections). The best include change order clauses specifying: (a) 24-hour notice for additional costs, (b) Documentation requirements for unforeseen issues, and (c) Daily delay penalties after agreed deadlines (rare but negotiable).

mainEntity.name: Do deck projects require permits, and do you manage them?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most jurisdictions require permits for: (1) Decks over 30 inches high, (2) Attached structures, (3) Electrical (lighting/outlets). Professional contractors typically: (a) Pull permits ($150-$800 depending on scope), (b) Schedule inspections (footings, framing, final), and (c) Provide stamped engineering drawings if needed. Always confirm permit responsibility in writing - some contractors charge extra for this service.
